stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream prototyping a new snowman enemy and iterating on the first room of the large ice-castle level, while chatting about optimization plans, naming ideas, and personal anecdotes.

development_findings.summary: A real-hardware test earlier in the day ran "near perfect" even without optimization, confirming the hack is viable on an actual N64.
development_findings.quote: It ran a lot better than I thought it would. It ran near perfect without even optimizing anything.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is importing Sauraen’s "trace" profiler to make locating performance issues and future optimizations much easier.
development_findings.quote: Once Sauraen's trace is in, it's going to be a lot easier to program. It's going to make optimization so much easier.

development_findings.summary: He is adding a toggleable anti-aliasing option; this is his current offline task.
development_findings.quote: My offline project right now is programming the anti-aliasing options so once we have that in we finally have a toggleable anti-aliasing.

development_findings.summary: The stream’s main coding task was a two-part snowman enemy: the head detaches, rolls toward Mario, then regenerates.  Kaze tuned scale, attack distance, rotation math, slope interaction, and plans glass-shatter effects for a star-reveal puzzle.
development_findings.quote: Next we need to program the glass shattering and we need to give it some wall bounce, and then we're good.

development_findings.summary: He replaced the full overworld with a minimalist test overworld to warp quickly into any stage while debugging.
development_findings.quote: The official RTY overworld is reduced to nothing again… this is important for testing.

development_findings.summary: Camera-based vertex lighting exists in the hack but is intentionally subtle to avoid a "strong effect."
development_findings.quote: Camera-based lighting does exist on Mario. It's just very hard to see because I made it very subtle.

development_findings.summary: Room-based culling will be used inside the castle to keep performance high; walls will hide adjacent rooms.
development_findings.quote: I haven't programmed the room system yet, but that's how it's gonna work… walls like this that look like ice is growing on it.

development_findings.summary: Level-design changes: entrance now shows penguin statues and the star immediately; slide sections may be removed; an ice "carpet" (possibly reflective) replaces barren floor areas.
development_findings.quote: This entrance is starting to look nice… Maybe the snowman should be a bit smaller… I think the sides are too barren, maybe an ice carpet.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a second star in every Bowser level, but notes it creates design parity issues.
development_findings.quote: If we add a second star in this Bowser level, we need to add two stars in every Bowser level.

development_findings.summary: Future goal: after Return to Yoshi's Island he wants to create his own original game, likely in Unreal.
development_findings.quote: When I finish this I'm probably going to make my own game at that point.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has several weeks off from his day job and plans to tackle long-postponed features during that time.
context_findings.quote: I have a bunch of time off from work, so I'm going to work on a bunch of features that I have put off for a long time.

context_findings.summary: He expects his first child in roughly two weeks and has moved house; Zeina now works in a separate office, explaining her reduced on-stream presence.
context_findings.quote: Can you believe it's just two weeks until my child is born… We moved and she now has her own office.

context_findings.summary: Kaze earns most income from an unrelated job; YouTube AdSense gives ~$5k/year, Patreon is higher.
context_findings.quote: I have a real job outside of YouTube… From AdSense I make around like $5,000 a year.

context_findings.summary: He shows light synesthesia, describing words as having a "minty" feel and associating smells/colors with concepts.
context_findings.quote: There has to be something deep inside you that associates words with sensations… I stepped into his house and was like dude your house smells so orange.

context_findings.summary: Expresses pragmatic view on voting: feels individual votes rarely change outcomes but sees personal pride value.
context_findings.quote: Never voted… To actually change the results of the election I don't think it's that effective.

biobak.summary: Provided feedback on snowman scale and level aesthetics (e.g., suggested ice carpet, questioned voice actor opinions).

zeina.summary: Active in chat; coined the term "trash pandas" for raccoons; her parents fully funded Kaze & Zeina’s weddings.
zeina.quote: This was all done by Zeina's parents and they are very generous people, so we had so much meat.

key_stories.title: Real N64 Performance Surprise
key_stories.summary: Kaze ran the current ROM build on an actual Nintendo 64 expecting major slow-downs but it performed almost flawlessly even before optimization.
key_stories.challenge: Unknown real-hardware performance could jeopardize release goals.
key_stories.process: Flashed the day’s build to N64, monitored frame-rate, compared to emulator.
key_stories.outcome: Confirmed the project is hardware-viable; optimization now framed as headroom rather than necessity.
key_stories.key_quote: It ran near perfect without even optimizing anything.

key_stories.title: Building the Rolling Snowman Enemy
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed and programmed a new snowman that detaches its head, rolls at Mario, and regrows—a core mechanic for the ice-castle level and a star puzzle.
key_stories.challenge: Needed a unique ice enemy that’s fun, readable, and performant.
key_stories.process: Sketched two-ball concept, debated animation with chat, coded hitbox, rotation math, scale tweaks, slope physics; next steps are glass-shatter and bounce.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype works in-game; attack rate and physics still being tuned.
key_stories.key_quote: Next we need to program the glass shattering and give it some wall bounce, and then we're good.

key_stories.title: Switching to a Minimal Test Overworld
key_stories.summary: To speed iteration Kaze replaced the elaborate overworld with a tiny hub, sacrificing aesthetics for efficiency during active development.
key_stories.challenge: Full overworld loads and camera paths slowed testing.
key_stories.process: Deleted most overworld geometry, kept simple pipes to every level.
key_stories.outcome: Rapid level swapping now possible; full overworld will be restored later.
key_stories.key_quote: Now we can test all the levels whenever we want.
